title: SB 1179
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 9002 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to define key terms related to public cemetery districts, such as "active militia" and "armed services." The board of trustees is also defined as the legislative body of a district. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to public cemetery districts, such as "active militia," "armed services," "board of trustees," "district," and "domestic partner." The curr_chunk defines "domestic partner" as adults in a committed relationship, "family member" as various relatives, and "firefighter" as per a specific section. An interment right allows the owner to control the use of a plot for human remains interment within a cemetery, including determining who can be interred and managing memorial markers. It is a transferable property interest governed by specific regulations. An interment right allows control over plot use for human remains interment, including managing memorial markers. It is transferable property governed by specific regulations. Nonresident defined as person outside district or not paying property taxes in district. Peace officer defined by Penal Code. Principal county has majority assessed property value in district. Chapter 5.5 (9069.10) of the Health and Safety Code defines terms like "peace officer," "principal county," and "voter" for interment rights. Chapter 5.5 of the Health and Safety Code defines interment rights, specifying that disinterment of human remains requires consent from the cemetery district and the surviving spouse, child, parent, or sibling in order of priority. Chapter 5.5 of the Health and Safety Code outlines rules for interment rights, requiring consent for disinterment from the cemetery district and specific family members. However, exceptions exist for the removal of remains within the same cemetery or by order of the court, coroner, or health department. The cemetery district must keep a duplicate copy of any removal order and maintain accurate records of the process. The cemetery district must maintain a duplicate copy of an order for the removal of remains, and keep accurate records including the date of removal, the person's name and age, the cemetery and plot of origin, and details of reinterment or alternate disposition. The person making the removal must provide detailed information including the name, age at death, cemetery, and plot of origin of the remains. If the remains are reinterred, details of the new plot and cemetery must be provided. If not reinterred, information on the alternate disposition should be recorded. The cemetery district must receive a complete record of the removal. An interment right grants a transferable property interest to the owner listed in the cemetery district records. The person removing remains must provide detailed information to the cemetery district, including a complete record of the removal. The owner of an interment right can designate who may be interred in the plot and must designate a successor owner at the time of purchase. The transfer of an interment right must comply with state and local laws and district policies. If the owner of an interment right dies without a valid disposition, the right passes according to intestate succession laws. If there are no heirs, the district follows abandonment procedures. When a public cemetery district transfers ownership rights based on an affidavit, they are not liable for any claims unless they had actual knowledge of false information provided. A successor owner of an interment right must sign an affidavit declaring their entitlement, efforts to find other claimants, and lack of opposition. Upon the sale of a plot in a cemetery, the district must notify the purchaser of any interment rights and the rules governing succession of ownership. The successor owner must sign an affidavit declaring their entitlement, efforts to find other claimants, and lack of opposition. The act does not require reimbursement for costs incurred by local agencies or school districts related to creating, eliminating, or changing penalties for crimes or infractions. The Commission on State Mandates will provide reimbursement to local agencies and school districts for costs mandated by the state, as outlined in the Government Code.
